title: Howland & Aspinwall
text:
Howland & Aspinwall was a merchant firm based in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> in the 1830s and 1840s. It specialized in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> trade, especially the importing of goods from <a href="Old%20China%20Trade">China</a>. It is best known for taking a pioneering role in the financing of <a href="clipper%20ship">clipper ship</a>s, especially the American-built "<a href="Rainbow%20%28clipper%29">Rainbow</a>" and "<a href="Sea%20Witch%20%28clipper%29">Sea Witch</a>".
History.
The firm, originally known as <a href="G.G.%20%26amp%3B%20S.S.%20Howland">G.G. & S.S. Howland</a>, was founded by brothers <a href="Gardiner%20Greene%20Howland">Gardiner Greene Howland</a> and <a href="Samuel%20Shaw%20Howland">Samuel Shaw Howland</a>. In 1832, upon the admission of their clerk, <a href="William%20Henry%20Aspinwall">William Henry Aspinwall</a>, the firm became known as Howland & Aspinwall.
Howland & Aspinwall imported high-status goods such as <a href="porcelain">porcelain</a>, <a href="silk">silk</a>, and <a href="tea">tea</a> from China, and sold them to Americans of means. Import duties paid by firms such as Howland & Aspinwall played a significant role in the financing of the American <a href="Federal%20budget%20%28United%20States%29">federal budget</a> during the 1840s. Howland & Aspinwall exported <a href="opium">opium</a> to China. 
Pacific Mail Steamship Company.
In 1848, as a result of the United States's acquisition of <a href="California">California</a>, partners G.S. Howland, S.S. Howland, and <a href="William%20Henry%20Aspinwall">William Henry Aspinwall</a> turned their attention from the China trade to California traffic. Improvements in the <a href="marine%20steam%20engine">marine steam engine</a> had begun to make clipper ships and other fast sailing ships obsolete. With other New York businessmen, the Howland and Aspinwall interests formed the <a href="Pacific%20Mail%20Steamship%20Company">Pacific Mail Steamship Company</a>. Pacific Mail eventually became <a href="American%20President%20Lines">American President Lines</a>, which is now part of <a href="Neptune%20Orient%20Lines">Neptune Orient Lines</a>.
Legacy.
Part of the Aspinwall family fortune was eventually bequeathed, through paternal grandmother <a href="Isaac%20Roosevelt%20%28businessman%29%23Personal%20life">Mary Aspinwall Roosevelt</a>, to <a href="Franklin%20D.%20Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>, 32nd President of the United States.
